text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, I'm Rob and welcome to 6 Minute English,
where today we're chatting about a pedestrian topic
and six items are related vocabulary.
Hello, I'm Neil. A pedestrian is someone who walks around
rather than travelling by car or bus,
but in Rob's sentence he used the adjective,
and in this context it means dull or uninteresting.
And of course I was making a pun, Neil,
because of course the show is going to be extremely interesting.
It's about safety on the streets,
and whether pedestrianisation is a good thing or not.
Pedestrianisation means changing a street into an area that can only be used by pedestrians.
speaker: Pedestrianisation

text: that can only be used by pedestrians.
Well, it sounds like a good idea.
No traffic, less noise and air pollution,
and no chance of getting knocked down by a car or a bus.
There are plans to pedestrianise Oxford Street,
There are plans to pedestrianise Oxford Street, which is one of the busiest shopping streets in London.
speaker: Neil

text: That's right, the mayor of London wants to tackle
or make an effort to deal with air pollution in this very busy spot,
where the amount of traffic is definitely a problem.
In fact, can you tell me, Neil, what's the average speed
of a bus travelling along Oxford Street?
a) 4.6 miles per hour,
speaker: tackle

text: b) 14.6 miles per hour or
speaker: tackle

text: And I think it's 14.6 miles per hour.
And I think it’s 14.6 miles per hour – a) sounds too slow and c) sounds too fast!
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, we'll find out the answer later on.
The problem is the traffic doesn't just disappear.
You ban it from one area and it gets re-rooted somewhere else.
Ban means to say officially that something can't be done,
and re-root means to change the direction you're travelling in
in order to reach a particular destination.
That's true, Rob.
It must be a big headache for city planners.
Well, let's listen now to Joe Irvin,
chief executive of Living Streets.
He's going to talk some more about why traffic
is causing problems in our towns and cities.
In 1970, we had 20 million cars in this country.
Now we have over 30 million cars in such a short period.
So that creates three big problems.
One is space because we still got the same street structures in our towns and cities,
causing congestion.
It causes pollution which people are concerned about more and more.
And actually, it's kind of engineering walking and out of our lives.
So we're actually not getting enough exercise
which is a cause of a health crisis.
Smart cities are looking at pedestrianisation in Glasgow,
in Birmingham, in London, for example, Manchester.
As a way of not only making their places cities better and more attractive,
actually building their local economy.
So Neil Irvin identifies three problems.
The first is that our city streets have stayed the same
while the number of cars on the roads has increased dramatically.
That's right.
And this has led to congestion on our roads.
That’s right – and this has led to congestion on our roads. Congestion means too much traffic, making it hard to move.
speaker: Congestion

text: The second problem is pollution – which we mentioned earlier.
speaker: Neil

text: Pollution is damage to the environment,
caused by releasing waste substances,
such as carbon dioxide into the air.
And the third problem is that by travelling around on buses or in our cars,
we aren't getting enough exercise.
And we all know that's a bad thing.
Would pedestrianisation engineer walking back into our lives, do you think?
I'm not sure, Neil.
It would be great if we could go shopping or walk to work without breathing in fumes
or worrying about getting knocked down by a car.
But banning all motorised traffic from town centres
might make life difficult for people to get around.
Well, I'm not a town planner and I don't have the answers.
Well, I’m not a town planner – and I don’t have the answers. But I would like to know if I got the answer right to the question you asked me earlier!
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, well, I asked you, what's the average speed of a bus
travelling along Oxford Street?
Is it a 4.6 miles per hour,
b 14.6 miles per hour,
c) 46 miles per hour?
speaker: tackle

text: And I said 14.6 miles per hour.
And that's not slow enough, Neil, I'm afraid.
The answer is actually 4.6 miles per hour.
And we pedestrians walk at an average speed of 3.1 miles per hour, apparently.
Uh-oh, good to know.
Okay, shall we go over the words we learnt today, Rob?
Sure.
The first one is pedestrian, a person who is walking,
usually in an area where there's traffic.
Sorry, you can't ride your bike here.
The path is for pedestrians only.
The adjective – ‘This book is full of very pedestrian ideas. I wouldn’t read it if I were you.’
speaker: Neil

text: I wouldn't read it if I were you.
I've cross it off my list, Neil, thank you.
Okay, number two is to tackle something,
which means to make an effort to deal with a difficult problem.
For example, the government isn't really tackling the problem of air pollution.
It needs to do much more.
Very true.
Okay, ban means to say officially that something can't be done.
The UK government will ban the sale of diesel and petrol cars
from 2040.
And number four is re-root, which means to change the direction you're travelling in.
The council has re-rooted all buses to avoid the town centre.
‘Congestion’ is number five – too much traffic, making it difficult to move.
speaker: Rob

text: ‘Road congestion always gets better in the summer when a lot of car drivers are on holiday.’
speaker: Neil

text: That's true, isn't it?
That’s true, isn’t it? London always seems emptier in July and August.
speaker: Rob

text: Except for all the tourists walking around – congesting the streets!
speaker: Neil

text: congesting the streets.
Very funny.
And finally, number six is pollution,
which is damaged to the environment caused by releasing waste substances,
such as carbon dioxide into the air or plastic into the sea.
You can help produce air pollution by walking to work every day instead of driving.
You're talking to me, Neil.
I always walk to work.
I know you do, Rob.
I know you do, Rob – you’re an example to us all!
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, that's all we have time for today.
But please don’t forget to visit us via our Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages! Goodbye!
speaker: Neil

text: Facebook and YouTube pages.
Goodbye.
Bye-bye.
